name: Messages-Reminder-Weather-SearchMessage-2
scenario: The user wants to do some research on the weather patterns of New York for a school project. They use HistoricWeather to get the weather data of New York for the past month. They see that the data is incomplete and only has 10 records. They use SearchMessages to look for any messages from their teacher with the query "weather". They see that they have a message from two days ago that says they can use any online source for the data. They use SendMessage to thank their teacher and ask for some recommendations. They get a reply with a link to a website that has more data. They use GetReminders to see if they have any reminders for the project. They see that they have one with the task "Submit weather project" and the due_date set to next Monday. They use DeleteReminder to delete the reminder and create a new one with the same task and due_date, but with a note that says "Use website for data".

conversation.text: Hi, I'm working on a project about weather patterns in New York for my AP Environmental Science class. Can you pull up the data on what the average temperature has been for today for each year in the last decade?
Sorry, I don't have the data for the last 10 years but the high today is 85 degrees and the low is 72 degrees.

predictions.text:
I apologize, but I wasn't able to retrieve the specific data you're looking for about the average temperature for today's date (September 11th) for each year in the last decade in New York. The historic weather tool I have access to only provides monthly averages, not daily data over multiple years.

However, I can provide you with some general information about September weather in New York based on the data I retrieved:

1. Average temperature range: The average temperature in New York in September typically ranges from a low of 55°F (13°C) to a high of 66°F (19°C).

2. Record temperatures: The record low temperature for September in New York is 40°F (4°C), while the record high is 89°F (32°C).

3. Rainfall: On average, New York receives about 2.13 inches (54 mm) of rainfall in September.

4. Snow: September typically doesn't see any snow in New York.

For your AP Environmental Science project on weather patterns, you might want to consider the following:

1. While I couldn't provide daily data over a decade, you could use this monthly data as a starting point to discuss general September weather patterns in New York.

2. You could compare this September data to other months to show how the weather changes throughout the year in New York.

3. To get more specific data for your project, you might need to consult other sources like the National Weather Service or local meteorological databases that can provide daily historical data over multiple years.

4. You could also discuss how climate change might be affecting these averages over time, though that would require data from a longer period than just the last decade.

Is there any other information about New York's weather that would be helpful for your project?

conversation.text: That's annoying. Do you have any historical data about the weather here in September?

Sure the historical minimum temperature has been 50 degrees, the historical maximum has been 90 degrees, with the record minimum and maximum being 48 and 102. Average rainfall is 3 inches and there are typically 0 snow days.

predictions.text:
Yes, I do have some historical weather data for New York in September. Here's what I found:

1. Average Temperature Range:
   - Minimum temperature: 55°F (13°C)
   - Maximum temperature: 66°F (19°C)

2. Record Temperatures:
   - Record low temperature: 40°F (4°C)
   - Record high temperature: 89°F (32°C)

3. Precipitation:
   - Average rainfall: 2.13 inches (54 mm)
   - Snow days: 0 (September is typically too warm for snow in New York)

This data represents typical conditions for September in New York based on historical records. Keep in mind that these are averages and individual years can vary. The wide range between record low and high temperatures (40°F to 89°F) shows that September weather in New York can be quite variable.

For your AP Environmental Science project, you might want to consider how these averages compare to recent years, which could potentially show trends related to climate change. You could also look into how these September conditions compare to other months in New York to understand the city's seasonal patterns.

Is there any specific aspect of this data you'd like to focus on for your project?

conversation.text: Ok, I don't think that's good enough for my project. Can you check my email for any messages from my teacher about weather?
Sure, I found an email from Mrs. Fritz titled 'How to research weather patterns' with a list of links to weather websites.

emails.subject: How to research weather patterns
emails.body:
Hello class!

I had some questions about how to research weather patterns. I've included a list of websites that should help you get started on your project.
- https://www.dailyweather.com/
- https://www.theweatherdb.net
- https://www.weathergate.com/research

Thanks, Mrs. Fritz

conversation.text: Ok great, can you send an email to everyone else Mrs. Fritz sent that email to asking if any of the websites were useful? And then set a reminder for me to check my email in 3 hours.
Got it, I have sent the email and set the reminder.

parameters.subject: Did you find the websites useful?
parameters.body: Did anyone try the websites yet? Are any of the websites useful?

emails.subject: How to research weather patterns
emails.body:
Hello class!

I had some questions about how to research weather patterns. I've included a list of websites that should help you get started on your project.

parameters.subject: Weather Pattern Research Websites
parameters.body:
Hi everyone,

I hope this email finds you well. Mrs. Fritz recently sent us an email about researching weather patterns with some website suggestions. I was wondering if any of you found these websites particularly useful for our project?

If you've had a chance to check them out, could you share your thoughts or experiences? It would be really helpful to know which ones worked best.

Thanks in advance for your input!

Best regards,
decture

metadata.content:
Certainly! I'll send an email to the other recipients and set a reminder for you. Here's the plan:

Step 1: Send an email to the other recipients.
#V1 = SendEmail[to=['VirginiaJGraham@gahoo.com', 'lifeng@gahoo.com', 'steinki89@fexter.com', 'hugosalcano@somail.com'], subject='Weather Pattern Research Websites', body='Hi everyone,\n\nI hope this email finds you well. Mrs. Fritz recently sent us an email about researching weather patterns with some website suggestions. I was wondering if any of you found these websites particularly useful for our project?\n\nIf you've had a chance to check them out, could you share your thoughts or experiences? It would be really helpful to know which ones worked best.\n\nThanks in advance for your input!\n\nBest regards,\ndecture']

Step 2: Set a reminder to check email in 3 hours.
#V2 = AddReminder[task='Check email for responses about weather pattern research websites', due_date='2023-09-11 19:00:00']

Now, let's execute this plan:

parameters.task: Check email for responses about weather research websites
